comment_data.body:
```suggestion
  it('exists() can check a lua function', function()
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -3360,4 +3360,11 @@ describe('vim.keymap', function()
     eq(1, exec_lua[[return GlobalCount]])
   end)
 
+  it('exists can check a lua function', function()

comment_data.body: I don't think this works if `require` is used after `v:lua`

comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -331,6 +331,8 @@ The following changes to existing APIs or features add new behavior.
 
 • |vim.wait()| is no longer allowed to be called in |api-fast|.
 
+• Vimscript function |exists()| support check lua function.

comment_data.body: `require` may be followed by a quote directly.

The value pushed onto the stack is not used? This will always reach the `return true` statement below.
Also `module_name` includes quotes here.
this will be very uncommon so it should be the last condition, not the first. (micro-optimization, but still...)

comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -3360,4 +3360,31 @@ describe('vim.keymap', function()
     eq(1, exec_lua[[return GlobalCount]])
   end)
 
+  it('exists() can check a lua function', function()
+    command('lua _G.test = function() print("hello") end')
+    eq(true, exec_lua[[
+      return vim.fn.exists('v:lua.test') == 1
+    ]])
+
+    eq(true, exec_lua[[
+      return vim.fn.exists('v:lua.require("vim.lsp").with') == 1

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
    eq(true, exec_lua[[
      _G.test = function() print("hello") end
      return vim.fn.exists('v:lua.test') == 1
    ]])
```

comment_data.body: This is a lot of special-purpose code for a very uncommon use-case. Can we use `NLUA_EXEC_STATIC` , or some other way to avoid all this code ? https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/529498685bbcd4783bc0e816d6247118c9ffb9a7/src/nvim/api/vim.c#L1907
mpack is stdlib function..I don't think it can used in there.

comment_data.body: However using `v:lua.require'mpack'.decode` should work, as `require'mpack'.decode` exists.

comment_regular_data.body: I don't think using `lua_getglobal()` will work for `require()`ing modules in 'runtimepath'.
that will exec a lua string. in there we only want make sure the function exist.

> that will exec a lua string. in there we only want make sure the function exist.

? The "lua string" can take `...` args, as shown in the example I linked in https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/26485/files#r1422056337

title: feat(eval): exists() function supports checking v:lua functions
